attributes.title: Testing the undoing hypothesis in athletes–A pilot study
attributes.description:
Positive Psychology has gained a respectable amount of research for the past two decades and there are recent efforts to link this research field to sport psychology (Mann & Narula, 2017). Thereby, positive sport psychology could focus on the well-being and positive emotions in the context of sport (Mann & Narula, 2017, p. 153) and close the research gap in sport psychology which has mainly focused on emotional problems, stress, or anxiety (Salama-Younes, 2011, p. 112).
The broaden-and-build theory (Fredrickson, 1998, 2001) states that positive emotions “broaden people’s awareness in ways that, over time and with frequent recurrence, build consequential personal resources that contribute to their overall emotional and physical well-being” (Fredrickson & Joiner, 2018, p. 194). Part of the theory is the undoing hypothesis which describes positive emotions to act in service of homeostasis (Fredrickson & Levenson, 1998, p. 193). In detail, after a stressor, positive emotions are assumed to lead to a faster cardiovascular recovery which eventually is presumed to lead to better cardiovascular health. Research focusing on the undoing hypothesis so far applied hardly comparable designs due to the use of different stressors (e.g., active vs. passive), different positive emotion inductions (e.g., film, articles, cartoons, sound) and different cardiovascular outcome measurements (e.g., heart rate, heart rate variability, skin conductance, pulse transmission time; see review of 24 studies by Cavanagh & Larkin, 2018). Regardless of those different designs, none of the studies has focused on athletes so far.
However, the undoing hypothesis might be fruitful especially for this population. Athletes are not only under a lot of pressure and experience psychophysiological stress prior to competition (Ehrlenspiel, Graf, Kühn, & Brand, 2011), they (in some sports) have several competitions on one day. As psychophysiological stress is known to impact (sports) performance (see e.g., review by Rumbold, Fletcher, & Daniels, 2012; Salvador & Costa, 2009), it appears relevant to quickly recover from the first stressor (i.e., first competition) in order to be ready for the second stressor (i.e., second competition). Thus, it could for example be beneficial for athletes to be exposed to positive emotion inductions between competitions within one day. 
The previous research focusing on the undoing hypothesis might however, not be applicable for athletes as they differ with respect to psychophysiological stress responses in comparison to the previously studied populations. Athletes have shown to exhibit lower levels of cortisol (i.e., stress hormone), heart rate and state anxiety responses due to a psychosocial laboratory stressor (i.e., Trier Social Stress Test, TSST; see Rimmele et al., 2009). It is unclear whether this might also be true with respect to recovery from stress. Therefore, in a first step, the aim is to investigate the assumed effects of the undoing hypothesis in athletes.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1:
For both groups, we expect that the stress induction (short version of the TSST) will increase (a) cardiovascular activity (i.e., increase in heart rate, blood pressure; decrease in HRV) and (b) negative emotions as well as subjectively perceived arousal levels in comparison baseline levels. Additionally, we expect a decrease in positive emotions due to the stress induction in comparison to the baseline level.

Hypothesis 2 (main hypothesis):
We hypothesis that the positive emotion group will have lower levels of cardiovascular activity during and after the positive emotion induction in comparison to the neutral condition group.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: The participants are not aware of the actual aim of the study.

question.value:
In this pilot study, we aim to collect full data sets of 40 healthy competitive athletes (22 females) between 18 and 30 years that train at least twice a week and had their last competition not longer than 2 months ago. The goal will be to test 44 participants in case of data loss or participants being aware of the actual goal of the study. 
Stress will be induced using a shortened computerized version of the TSST. Emotions (positive vs. neutral) will be induced using guided imagery. Participants will be asked to imagine to brush their teeth (neutral condition) or to imagine their happiest moment (positive condition). Cardiovascular activity will be measured using heart rate, heart rate variability (SDNN, RMSSD, LF, HF, LF/HF; in accordance with Laborde et al., 2017), as well as diastolic and systolic blood pressure. Positive emotions will be assessed using the modified emotion differential scale (mDES; German version form Brandenburg & Backhaus, 2015). Valance and arousal will be assessed using the self-assessment manikins (SAM; Bradley & Lang, 1994).
Participants will first be informed about the study (i.e., cover story) and asked to sign a written consent form. After the ECG electrodes and the blood pressure, the manchette will be connected to the participant. While they are getting used to the devices, participants will be asked to answer socio-demographic questions. After this, the baseline assessment of all cardiovascular parameters (first HR & HRV, then blood pressure) will follow. Therefore, participants will be asked to close their eyes and sit still for 5 min (following the recommendations for assessing HRV of Laborde et al., 2017). Participants will then be asked to fill out the mDES and the SAM to assess baseline emotional states. After this, participants will be presented with a stressor (shortened computerized version of the TSST) and then given either a positive emotion induction (i.e., imagine your happiest moment) or a neutral emotion induction (i.e., image brushing your teeth; in accordance to Woodman et al., 2009). During the stressor and emotion induction, HR and HRV will be measured consistently. After the stressor and the emotion induction, blood pressure and emotional states will be measured again. A 5 min recovery phase will take place in which participants are asked to sit back for another 5 min and close their eyes. At the end of the recovery phase, blood pressure and emotional states will be assessed for the last time. Finally, participants are asked to fill out personality questionnaires (Brief Inventory of Thriving, Su et al., 2014; Orientation to Happiness, Ruch et al., 2014; modified differential emotional scale trait, Brandenburg & Backhaus, 2015) and answer control questions (e.g., How well were you able to engage in the imaginary task?) and questions with respect to the cover story (i.e., Did you know any of the cognitive tasks?; In short, what was the study about?). In the end, participants will be debriefed and thanked for their participation.   

Cover story
Participants will not fully be informed about the aim of the study to reduce social desirable answers. They will be told that the study investigates the relation between cognition and physiological reactions. “Quick thinking” (i.e., the first part of the TSST), “arithmetic” (i.e., the second part of the TSST) and “imagination” (i.e., imagine brushing your teeth vs. imagine your happiest moment) will be labeled as cognitive tasks. Participants will be fully debriefed at the end.

Exclusion criteria are any cardiovascular diseases or smoking.

q13.value: In this pilot study, we aim to collect full data sets of 40 healthy competitive athletes (22 females) between 18 and 30 years that train at least twice a week and had their last competition not longer than 2 months ago.

question.value: Stress will be induced using a shortened computerized version of the TSST. Emotions (positive vs. neutral) will be induced using guided imagery. Participants will be asked to imagine to brush their teeth (neutral condition) or to imagine their happiest moment (positive condition).

Cardiovascular activity will be measured using heart rate, heart rate variability (SDNN, RMSSD, LF, HF, LF/HF; in accordance with Laborde et al., 2017), as well as diastolic and systolic blood pressure. Positive emotions will be assessed using the modified emotion differential scale (mDES; German version form Brandenburg & Backhaus, 2015). Valance and arousal will be assessed using the self-assessment manikins (SAM; Bradley & Lang, 1994).

Participants will also be asked to fill out personality questionnaires (Brief Inventory of Thriving, Su et al., 2014; Orientation to Happiness, Ruch et al., 2014; modified differential emotional scale trait, Brandenburg & Backhaus, 2015) and answer control questions (e.g., How well were you able to engage in the imaginary task?) and questions with respect to the cover story (i.e., Did you know any of the cognitive tasks?; In short, what was the study about?). In the end, participants will be debriefed and thanked for their participation.

For all other participants, all variables will be checked for normal distribution and outliers (mean ± 3 SD). 
In a first step, we tested for baseline differences between the groups regarding cardiovascular variables, positive and negative emotions as well as valance and arousal. In a second step, a repeated measure analysis of variance (ANOVA) entering group (positive emotion condition vs. neutral emotion condition) as a between-subject factor and testing time (baseline vs. stress vs. emotion vs. recovery) as a within-subject factor will be run.

q22.value: Participants who were aware of the actual aim of the study (i.e., manipulation check question “What was the experiment about?” will be excluded from further analysis.

q23.value: In case of missing data on cardiovascular measurements, the participant will be excluded from further analyses.

q24.value: We plan to look for differences regarding to gender. We also plan to explore differences based on trait questionaires.

attributes.title: Radiation dose of prostatic artery embolisation for benign prostatic hyperplasia: protocol for a systematic review

q1.value: Radiation dose of prostatic artery embolisation for benign prostatic hyperplasia: protocol for a systematic review

q2.value: Valentin Zumstein, Jörg Binder, patrick betschart, Manolis Pratsinis, Gautier Müllhaupt, Lukas Hechelhammer, Hans-Peter Schmid, Dominik Abt

q3.value: Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) is a prevalent entity in elderly men and transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) still represents the gold standard of surgical treatment despite its considerable perioperative morbidity. Recently, prostatic artery embolization (PAE) was described as a novel effective and less invasive treatment alternative and evidence is growing including some prospective randomized controlled data which became available. Whereas efficacy of PAE is now a matter of fact, controversial discussions around the radiation dose which PAE patients are exposed to and its inherent stochastic and deterministic effects open the field for a systematic review of the current available literature.

q4.value:
Objectives (PICO):
Participants are patients with lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) due to BPH.
Intervention will be PAE.
Primary Outcome is Radiation Dose (Dose Area Product) per patient.
Secondary Outcomes are:
Correlation of radiation exposure and:
-	prostate size
-	Age of participants
-	Fluoroscopy Time
-	Specifications of PAE (source of radiation, type of microcatheter, cone-beam ct use)

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
We will conduct a systematic review following the PRISMA-P (Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic review and Meta-Analysis Protocols) 2015 checklist:
- We will include randomised controlled trials (RCTs) and prospective comparative trials as well as retrospective studies with at least 20 participants. All included trials report on primary or any secondary outcomes as defined above.  
- We will conduct a systematic search of three biomedical databases (York CRD, Embase, Medline) up to 18.01.2020.
- Records will be listed and stored in a citation software solution (Endnote TM)
Two independent reviewers will screen all titles and abstracts of all identified articles for appropriate study design and relevance of content. A third independent reviewer will solve disagreement. Trials that seem to meet inclusion criteria will then be reviewed as full text. 
Both reviewers will collect data using predefined data extraction sheets. Disagreements will be solved by a third independent reviewer.
Study design, baseline data, follow-up, outcomes and adverse events will be listed

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

- Search terms involve: (embolization, therapeutic (MeSH Terms)) AND (((prostatic OR prostate) AND (artery OR arterial) AND (embolization OR embolization))
- Records will be listed and stored in a citation software solution (Endnote TM)
Two independent reviewers will screen all titles and abstracts of all identified articles for appropriate study design and relevance of content. A third independent reviewer will solve disagreement. Trials that seem to meet inclusion criteria will then be reviewed as full text.

- descriptive statistics

attributes.title: Medicalisation of Female genital mutilation in Kenya
attributes.description: This projects  endeavors to understand why families choose to take their daughters for genital cutting by health professionals and why health professionals accept to offer those services

summary.value: The data set contains responses on why families opt for their daughters to be performed genital mutilation by health care providers and the reasons the health professionals accept to cut the girls. This was a qualitative research that utilized focus group discussions, in depth interviews and key informant interviews to collect the data. The data was collected from women in the reproductive age, mothers or legal guardians to girls, fathers or male partners, community leaders, health care providers, as well as representatives from NGOs and CSOs

registration_responses.summary: The data set contains responses on why families opt for their daughters to be performed genital mutilation by health care providers and the reasons the health professionals accept to cut the girls. This was a qualitative research that utilized focus group discussions, in depth interviews and key informant interviews to collect the data. The data was collected from women in the reproductive age, mothers or legal guardians to girls, fathers or male partners, community leaders, health care providers, as well as representatives from NGOs and CSOs

attributes.title: Life History Trade-offs and Menstrual Cycle Length and Regularity

q1.value: Life History Trade-offs and Menstrual Cycle Length and Regularity

q3.value: We received data from Flo period tracking app on the cycle lengths of 20,000 women each month for 12 months. In addition, we received how often these women logged engaging in a variety of sexual behaviors and experiencing a number of health problems.

q4.value: Consistent with our previous cross-sectional research (Gassen et al., 2019), we predict that women investing more in mating effort will have shorter, more regular cycles. While in our previous work we predicted that changes in mating effort would precede shifts in cycle length, we will test the direction of this relationship in the current project.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Women using the Flo period tracking app reported their cycle lengths for 12 months. They also reported the number of health problems they experienced each month and their frequency of sexual behaviors.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

Age (years), weight (kg), relationship status, smoker status, chronic illness status, race, cycle length, cycle regularity (to be computed  as a latent factor of variability in cycle lengths across time), number of times engaging in or reporting (a) protected sex, (b) unprotected sex, (c) high sex drive, (d) masturbation, (e) fatigue, (f) insomnia, and (g) cravings.

Given that cycle lengh is not expected to vary systematically as a function of time, we will analyze the data using a random intercept cross-lagged panel model. q1.value: The representation of women authors in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM): a systematic review

q2.value: Janet, Emma Wilson, Til Wykes, Phillip Staite

q3.value:
Studies have shown that academia is a male-dominated field, particularly in the STEM subjects (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) (Moss-Racusin et al., 2012). Numerous initiatives have tried to tackle this issue, but new research has shown that gender inequality persists as globally ‘women’ account for fewer than 30% of STEM authorships (Larivière et al., 2013). 

An important step in tackling the issue of gender inequality is getting data on the nature of authorship as this is a significant metric for measuring academic success (Ioannidis, 2014). Although researchers have already published articles and reviews on this topic, not much focus has been on how ‘women’ and ‘men’ have been defined in such studies. For example, usually based purely on convenience, researchers have either manually assigned gender based on personal judgments of an author’s online profile for small samples, or they have relied on algorithms such as genderize.io that predict an individual’s gender based on inaccessible databases of social network profiles for larger samples (Wais, 2016). Discussions about the limitations of these methodologies are usually only contained to the precision and accuracy of the classification and not about what these classifications truly represent (Holman et al., 2018).

As the definitions of ‘women’ and ‘men have changed over the years, there is a need to re-examine past methodologies and findings in today’s context (Diamond, 2004). This is particularly true as past studies have relied on surface-level classifications of gender that is likely to have not captured the true picture of what it means to be a ‘woman’ in STEM. This study will therefore review past and recent findings, and in doing so will provide a fresh perspective on the current barriers and challenges that are currently present in pursuit of gender equality in academia.

References

Diamond, M. (2004). Sex, gender, and identity over the years: a changing perspective. Child and Adolescent Psychiatric Clinics of North America, 13(3). doi: 10.1016/j.chc.2004.02.008

Holman, L., Stuart-Fox, D., & Hauser, C. E. (2018). The gender gap in science: How long until women are equally represented? PLoS Biology, 16(4).

Ioannidis, J. P. A. (2014). How to Make More Published Research True. PLoS Medicine, 11(10). 

Larivière, V., Ni, C., Gingras, Y., Cronin, B., & Sugimoto, C. R. (2013). Bibliometrics: Global gender disparities in science. Nature, 504(7479), 211-213. doi:10.1038/504211a

Moss-Racusin, Corinne A., John F. Dovidio, Victoria L. Brescoll, Mark J. Graham, and Jo Handelsman. “Science Faculty’s Subtle Gender Biases Favor Male Students.” PNAS 109, no. 41 (2012): 16474–79. https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.1211286109.

Wais, K. (2016). Gender Prediction Methods Based on First Names with genderizeR. The R 
Journal, 8(1).

q4.value: Objective: To examine how women are being represented in STEM publications through a retrospective review with account taken of how gender is classified.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Systematic literature review

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value:
Our study will qualitatively summarize the results of existing primary studies that investigate how women are being represented in STEM publications, with account taken of how gender is classified.

At the time of pre-registration, a preliminary literature search has been conducted to ensure that an adequate number of studies exist to warrant a systematic review.

question.value:
Type of Publication:
Only original papers and reviews will be included.

Peer Review:
Only studies that have been peer-reviewed will be included.

Language:
Only studies in English will be included.

Study design:
Retrospective, observational and analytical study designs will be included. Letters and conference papers will not be included.

Reported Outcomes:
The primary outcome of interest is the proportion of women authors in STEM publications. Therefore, if a study does not have figures reporting on this outcome, either in percentages or proportions, it will not be included.

The selection process of studies will help determine which studies found are to be used in the systematic review. 

Selection process:
The relevant studies obtained from the various sources will be collected, and duplicates will be removed to reduce the workload during screening. 

Information sources:
The search for studies will be in the following electronic databases: MEDLINE (OVID interface), EMBASE (OVID interface), PsychINFO (OVID interface), CINAHL, Web of Science, and BASE. The reference lists of the included studies or reviews that are identified through the search will also be looked at.

Search strategy:
The following search terms will be used to search the databases: “representation” OR “proportion” AND “women” OR “female” AND “authorship” OR “authors” AND “publications”

Initial screening will involve applying selection criteria to the titles and/or abstracts of references, and not the full text. This will be performed independently by two reviewers. After screening, the references from both reviewers will be collected and compared. The set of references that are overlapping will be included for the next step of screening. The non-overlapping references that the reviewers did not agree on will be decided on in a meeting between the two reviewers. 

The last step of screening will have two independent reviewers applying the selection criteria to the full texts of the references that passed the initial stage. Those that are agreed upon will be included in the systematic review.

q13.value: All studies found in the literature search that meet the inclusion criteria will be included in the systematic review.

q15.value: The initial search will be conducted in spring 2020 and will continue until  “saturation.” (i.e., only redundant studies are obtained through searches). Once this occurs, we will contact authors for any relevant texts that can't be sourced in full, and then begin analysing the data.

question.value: Not applicable.

Main outcomes 
-	Author names of study
-	Method of gender classification (e.g. manual inspection or use of algorithm)
-	Discussions surrounding gender and sex
-	Discipline/topic
-	Focus/scope (e.g. journals, department)
-	Year(s) sampled
-	Sample size (number of articles used for gender analysis)
-	% of women authors (overall)
-	% of women first authors
-	% of women last/senior authors

Additional outcomes 
-	Whether % of women authors (overall) changed over time
-	Whether % of women first authors changed over time
-	Whether % of women last/senior authors changed over time
-	Factors identified as being significantly correlated with women authorship % 
-	Method of predicting factors associating with women authorship % (i.e. statistical method used)

Simple descriptive statistics will be used to describe the findings of the papers identified to create summary statistics. The methodologies used for each study will also be compared (e.g. method of gender classification and discipline/topic)

q22.value:
1. Research papers that are not reviews or original papers
2. Studies that are not peer-reviewed 
3. Studies not written in English
4. Letters and conference papers 
5. Studies without the primary outcome of interest: the proportion of women authors in STEM publications. Therefore, if a study does not have figures reporting on this outcome, either in percentages or proportions, it will not be included.

q1.value: Moderating role of neuroticism on the relationship between household income and life satisfaction in adolescence

q3.value: There's some evidence that there's a positive relationship between household income and life satisfaction in adolescence. But is this relationship the same for different income groups? And what is the role of neuroticism on this relationship?

q4.value:
- There's a positive effect of household income on life satisfaction in adolescence. This effect is stronger in lower income groups.

- Adolescents with high scores on neuroticism experience less life satisfaction

- The relationship between household income and life satisfaction increases as neuroticism increases

attributes.title: The Robustness of the Featural Justification Bias

q1.value: Can warning about confidence-accuracy conflation mitigate the biasing impact of knowledge of the police suspect?

q2.value: Jesse Howard Grabman, Chad Dodson, Daniella Cash, Crystal R Slane

q3.value:
In the two previous experiments, we found that warnings about confidence-accuracy conflation can abolish the featural justification effect. In this experiment, we address the effect of the warning when a) effect sizes are potentially larger than seen in the featural justification effect, b) the accuracy of the witness's statement is (un-)corroborated by outside information, and c) a different bias is at play.

The within-subject conditions mirror the Grabman & Dodson (2019) paper on the impact of knowing the identity of a police suspect on interpretations of eyewitness statements. In this study, we found that participants rated eyewitness statements as more confident when the eyewitness identified the police suspect, as compared to a condition where the suspect was unknown. This is a logical error, because participants were explicitly told (and acknowledged) that the witness did not know the identity of the police suspect when making their selection, meaning that this information should not influence the witness's intended level of confidence.

Will the same warning from the previous featural justification experiments reduce the impact of knowing the identity of the police suspect? This question has important real-world implications, as often legal decisions (e.g., whether to admit eyewitness testimony in court) are made with the identity of the suspect in mind. A witness may be perceived as more confident than is warranted if their selection matches the police suspect. Additionally, research suggests that picking someone other than the police suspect (i.e.,  a filler) should be considered evidence against the police suspect, meaning that downplaying the importance of disconfirmations could decrease exoneration rates.

q4.value:
1. We expect to replicate previous findings on contextual effects when participants receive no warning. Specifically, as compared to a condition where the suspect is unknown (no-context), we expect that participants will perceive identical confidence statements as more certain when witnesses' selections match the police suspect (suspect-Id). We also hypothesize that identical confidence statements will be perceived as less certain when witnesses' selections do not match the police suspect (filler-Id).

2. We expect that knowledge of the police suspect will be less impactful on participants receiving the confidence-accuracy conflation warning. Specifically, there will be a smaller difference between the no-context condition and the two bias conditions (suspect-Id; filler-Id), as compared to the no-warning condition.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: The study is a 3 (Context: suspect-Id, foil-Id, no-context; within) x 2 (Warning: warning vs. none; between) mixed design.

q9.value: All participants are randomized into two possible groups (warning vs. no warning). Statement order and Context are counterbalanced across participants.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Data will be collected on the Qualtrics platform using TurkPrime for participant recruitment. Participants will be paid $.50 for up to 30 minutes of their time. Participants will need to pass initial attention checks (i.e., ensure they have read and understood all instructions) to complete the survey. Specifically there is a check for the presence of bots (entering a key word), completion of an example task, and two comprehension questions after reading the instructions. We also implement an IP screening protocol to block responses originating from a virtual private server (VPS), or outside the United States (see Kennedy et al., 2018 for details).

q13.value: We will recruit 100 participants per warning condition (200 total)

q14.value: A power analysis using G*Power showed that this sample size is sufficient to detect an interaction effect with an effect size of f = .25 at 95% power with an alpha = .05.

question.value:
1. Participants respond to the prompt "The witness is _____% certain in their selection" on a scale ranging from 0 (not at all certain) to 100 (completely certain) in 20% increments. 

2. Follow-up questions:

a. What information did you use to help you determine the eyewitness's intended level of confidence? (open-ended)
b. When judging the statements, did you consider the accuracy of the witness's response? Please be honest! (Yes/No)

1. We plan to run a standard two-way mixed ANOVA, with follow-up planned contrasts between the no-context condition and (a) suspect-Id and (b) filler-Id conditions for each of the warning groups. A Bayes Factor score will quantify the likelihood of observing the null vs. research hypothesis for each planned contrast. 

2. We will use logistic regression to examine the follow-up question of whether participants considered accuracy before making their response (Yes/No ~ Statement * Warning)

q22.value:
Participants must pass each of the manipulation checks to be considered for analysis:

1. Correct answer to a question to exclude bots.
2. Correct answer on both smiley example lineups.
3. Correct answers on 4 instruction comprehension questions.

Additionally we will exclude responses with duplicate IP addresses, or use of a mobile device.

q25.value:
Please see the following paper for a similar design: 

Grabman, J. H., & Dodson, C. S. (2019). Prior knowledge influences interpretations of eyewitness confidence statements:‘The witness picked the suspect, they must be 100% sure'. Psychology, Crime & Law, 25(1), 50-68.

2. We will use logistic regression to examine the follow-up question of whether participants considered accuracy before making their response (Yes/No ~ Statement * Warning)

attributes.title: Identifying gaps in women's football research -- a systematic scoping review

q1.value: Identifying gaps in women’s football research – a systematic scoping review

q3.value: Research on female football (soccer) is limited and a rapidly increasing global interest and development of the female side of the sport has occurred over the past decade. Yet, limited research is currently available in comparison to the male counterparts. This scoping review aims to identify and map peer reviewed publications presenting data on female football research. The search will focus on all research disciplines within female football covering. Peer-reviewed studies are extracted from five relevant databases and published in one of the four FIFA languages (English, French, Spanish and German).

q4.value:
This study aims to explore the current state of female football research by identifying the types of evidence available. 

Hypotheses for Scoping reviews are unorthodox. Yet, based on researcher observations it can be hypothesised that limited research in available on female football.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: Blinding will follow the PRISMA-ScR guidelines and Liberati et al. (2009) and be carried out during step (9) selection of sources of evidence and initial phase of (10) data charting process. Any conflict will be settled by a third independent reviewer.

question.value:
Data collection follows the PRISMA-ScR guidelines

A search of five online databases (PubMed, PsycINFO, Web of Science, Scopus, and SPORTDiscus) will be carried out to elucidate any papers on women's football. 

Articles extracted from the databases were saved in Mendeley referencing tool. Duplicates were removed and uploaded onto Rayyan QCRI, (Qatar Computing Research Institute, Doha, Qatar) where blinded inclusion/exclusion was performed by two independent researchers using the below-listed inclusion/exclusion criteria on titles and abstracts for each article. 

Inclusion criteria include:
-	Female football (soccer)
-	Official FIFA language (English, French, Spanish, and German)
-	Published in peer reviewed journal
-	All levels of ability
-	All years of publication
-	All study types
-	All subjects concerning women’s football
Exclusion criteria include:
-	Papers with female data merged with male data
-	Mixed sex football
-	No player sex mentioned in abstract
-	Females in male football (referees, fans, coaches, other staff, agents, personal relationships)
-	Street, beach, or futsal style football
-	Football data merged with other sports
-	Football performed on the playground or in physical education lessons.
-	Football to American, Australian, Gaelic football or rugby footballl rather than association football
-	Non-peer reviewed literature, abstracts, theses, books
-	Opinion pieces 

Any conflict will be settled by a third independent reviewer.

attributes.title: Study 3 - replication and extension of Study 1
attributes.description:
After Study 2 failed to show the expected results, we reconsidered our theorizing. It is possible that the effect found in Study 1 was spurious, explaining the lack of consistent effects in Study 2. Alternatively, it is possible that the fictitious goddess used in Study 2 was processed in a way sufficiently different from how religious people view the God they actually believe in to obviate the effects observed in Study 1. 

Therefore, we seek to replicate the effects in Study 1 while also probing associated processes, for example that of rationalizing a punishing god.

q1.value: Study 3 - Regulatory focus and new information about God

q2.value: Anand Krishna, Felix Johannes Götz, Teresa Kaudewitz

q3.value:
In Study 1, initial correlative evidence for a connection between a chronic promotion focus and a view of God as nurturing was established. In addition, evidence was found for a correlation between chronic prevention focus and a view of God as punishing, albeit of a weaker magnitude. Situational regulatory focus was manipulated, but showed no effect in this study.

Study 2 attempted to generalize the findings from Study 1 to the perception of a fictitious goddess. Participants read stories written in a religious tone about said goddess and subsequently judged her behavior in the story as either punishing or nurturing. If chronic regulatory focus influences the processing of new information about godlike figures, similar correlations to those observed in Study 1 should have obtained for the ratings of the goddess’ behavior. However, no reliable evidence was found for these predictions. 

Study 2 suffered from several methodical shortcomings. First, the online structure of the experiment required the use of strong attention checks to ensure valid data. However, this necessitated a reward structure that was contingent on participants’ attention, thereby possibly inducing a focus on rewards (i.e. a situational promotion focus). Second, the online data collection suffered from a bug that led to an undetermined number of participants seeing an older version of the experiment (see https://www.millisecond.com/forums/Topic25012.aspx). Third, the stories describing the goddess’ behavior were written for this study and not pretested for content. This led to participants seeing not just ambivalent stories in which the goddess showed both punishing and nurturing tendencies, but also univalent stories in which she was only punishing or only nurturing. The presence of the univalent stories might have given a proportion of participants a specific unambiguous initial image of the goddess, rendering later judgments less likely to be affected by regulatory focus. Finally and perhaps most importantly, there may be important psychological differences between processing information about a fictitious godlike figure and the God in which one believes. 

For these reasons, we decided to discontinue our inquiries into the processing of information about godlike figures and instead focus on replicating and extending our initial findings with regard to views of God. Therefore, we plan a study in which religious university students are queried on their views of God in general as well as their chronic regulatory focus, allowing a direct replication of the initial study.

In addition, we have adapted several of our vignettes to the Christian God. Using participants’ evaluations of God’s behavior in these vignettes, we seek to investigate whether participants are motivated to reconcile punishing behavior by God with their presumably positive general image of God by assigning the recipients of said punishment the responsibility for their negative outcomes. Participants who do not view God as punishing should be most likely to engage in such attributions in order to reconcile the inconsistency of God’s behavior in the story with their view of God as nonpunishing. In particular, such participants with a strong chronic prevention focus should be particularly agitated by punishing behavior from God due to their increased sensitivity to negative outcomes and also particularly likely to condemn those punished by God due to their focus on avoiding violations of moral standards. Such rationalization processes might also partially explain the comparatively weaker correlation between chronic prevention focus and views of God as punishing found in Study 1.

q4.value:
H1 (replication hypothesis): Participants’ chronic promotion focus correlates positively with their view of God as nurturing. Participants’ chronic prevention focus correlates positively with their view of God as punishing.

H2 (new information processing hypothesis): Participants with a strong chronic promotion focus interpret new information about God in such a way as to judge him as more nurturing. Participants with a strong chronic prevention focus interpret new information about God in such a way as to judge him as more punishing. 

H3 (rationalization hypothesis): Participants’ chronic prevention focus influences to what degree they assign responsibility for negative outcomes towards those punished by God.

H3a: Participants who strongly view God as punishing assign less blame to the recipients of punishment by God than participants who weakly view God as punishing.

H3b: The pattern described in H3a is more pronounced for individuals with a strong chronic prevention focus than for those with a weak chronic prevention focus.

See attached file for formulations.
Scale items will be aggregated to mean values.

All predictor variables will be grand-mean centered prior to analysis.
H1 will be evaluated using multiple regression models for the criterion variables punishing view of God and nurturing view of God in general. Each model will include the relevant chronic regulatory focus score (prevention => punishing; promotion => nurturing) as a main predictor and the other chronic regulatory focus score as well as religiosity scores as control variables. The critical effects will be the B parameter estimates for the relevant regulatory focus scores (criterion: p ≤ .05). Note that these regression models are identical to those calculated in Study 1.
H2 will be evaluated using restricted likelihood multilevel models for the criterion variables punishing view of God and nurturing view of God in the stories. Each model will include subject intercept and story intercept as random effects. The relevant chronic regulatory focus score (prevention => punishing; promotion => nurturing) will be included as a main predictor and the other chronic regulatory focus score as well as religiosity scores as control variables, analogously to the regression models for H1. The critical effects will be the F tests for the main effects of the relevant regulatory focus scores (criterion: p ≤ .05). The model structure is chosen to maximize comparability between the analyses for H1 and H2.
For H3, the items measuring blame attribution to those punished by God will be aggregated to a mean as a criterion variable. A restricted likelihood multilevel model with subject intercept and story intercept as random effects and punishing view of God in general, chronic prevention focus and their interaction term as predictors will be calculated. The critical effects will be the main effect of punishing view of God (H3a) and the interaction term (H3b, criteria: p ≤ .05) in the F tests.

attributes.title: Can ST-IATs predict collection of litter?

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Can behavioral ST-IATs predict collection of litter?

other.value: Next to the main question, we compare which of the ST-IATs distinguishes best between the groups (based on the logistic regression), whether the ST-IAT scores correlate with the explicit measure of the same constructs, and we analyze with multiple regression analyses whether the expected utility of a behavior predicts the IAT scores/ group membership and the scores of the explicit measure. For the measurement of the expected utilities we explore two different measures. One measure in which the value of the outcome and the expectancy to reach this outcome are measured in separate items and one measure in which we measure these two aspects within the same items. For these measurement we also explore which outcome is the most important in the prediction of the implicit and explicit attitude towards the behavior, the group membership, and the intention to engage in the behavior.

sample.value: We will collect data from 210 participants per condition (per ST-IAT). The total sample size will therefore be 630 participants. This sample size is determined based on a power analysis performed with G*Power for a medium effect size of  0.5, an alpha level of 0.05, and a power of 0.95.

analyses.value:
In the first analysis we will conduct three independent t-tests to investigate whether the D-scores of the ST-IATs differ between groups of collectors and non-collectors. For each ST-IAT one independent t-test will be performed.
In the second part of the analysis we will perform three logistic regressions. In each logistic regression the D-score of one ST-IAT will serve as the independent variable and group membership (i.e. collectors or non-collectors) as the categorical outcome variable.

outliers.value:
We adhere to the recommendations from Greenwald et al. (2003) for the exclusion of trials and participants in the ST-IAT scores. 
Furthermore, participants will be asked to answer the pre-screening question once again at the end of the study. Participants for whom the reported frequency of the investigated behavior differs strongly compared to the answer in the pre-screening questionnaire will be excluded. In particular, participants will be excluded if they would not be classified as members of the same group as they were based on the pre-screening questionnaire.

dependent.value:
In a first analysis the difference scores (D-scores) from the ST-IATs will serve as the dependent variable. The D-scores will be calculated according to the procedure proposed by Greenwald et al. (2003). We will calculate one D-score per ST-IAT. The three ST-IATs are an evaluative ST-IAT (good/bad), a liking ST-IAT (like/dislike), and a wanting ST-IAT (want/don't want).
In a second analysis group membership (i.e. collectors or non-collectors) will serve as a categorical outcome variable. The assignment to the different groups will be based on a prescreening questionnaire. The prescreening consist of a single question, asking how often a person collects litter outside. The rating is given on a 5-point likert scale (never, rarely, sometimes, often, almost always). We only select participants from the lower spectrum of the scale (i.e., the non-collectors) and the higher spectrum (i.e., the collectors).

conditions.value: Participants are randomly assigned to perform one of three ST-IATs (three conditions).

hypothesis.value: This study is part of a project examining whether implicit measures that measure an attitude towards a behavior are superior to implicit measures that measure an attitude towards a stimulus or stimulus feature. In the current study we want to examine whether three different types of Single-target IATs (ST-IATs) are able to distinguish between people frequently or rarely executing a specific behavior (i.e., collecting litter). We hypothesize that the ST-IAT scores differ significantly between these people and thus that they are predictive of group membership.
